page.title: 04PLACE-NAMES IN BEGUILDY
page.content: The Welsh language became almost extinct in this area well over a hundred years ago. It is on record that two hundred years ago the demand for Welsh was so limited that a Welsh service once a month at the Parish Church met the requirements of the parishioners. However, though the Welsh language ceased to be used in the parish so long ago, the names of the hills, fields and farms are still retained in pure Welsh. Beguildy is an anglicised form of the Welsh name " Bugeildy" which means "Shepherd's House", an obvious reference to the main occupation of the villagers. Many farm names are Welsh although some pronunciations are English "Llanllwyd" means "Greychurch", "Carreg-y-Frain" means"Crows' Stone" and "Cwmbugail" is translated as "Shepherd's Valley". Most of the hills have Welsh names.
